WRITING.TEXT: Bee Culture need a better proofreader. And a better layout designer wouldn't hurt. But I still enjoy it.

WRITING.TITLE: Still my favorite cover art from any edition of the DMG.

WRITING.TEXT: SCOTUS might decline to hear the case, for a variety of reasons, some of them very technical. Not everything big goes to the high court.
Thanks! I need a cheat sheet to keep track of the retroclones. Anyway, this is a cool monster, and I shall use it in my (2E) campaign.

WRITING.TITLE: Some love for the Second Edition fighter via new kits.

WRITING.TEXT: This is cool! However, I'm not familiar with the "Hoard Class" and "Save" entries in the statistics. What OSR system? (There are so many retroclones, it's hard to keep up.)
I think Reuters probably contains the least amount of bias, but every report will probably be slightly skewed, no matter the source.
Weasel News: Confirming Your Prejudices!

WRITING.TEXT: They'll release one right before they announce 6E. That's usually how it works.

I think DARLENE is just a single-name person, like Cher. You don't need to include her last name for us to know who you're talking about.
Edit: Yep, she legally eliminated her last name in 1984.
The 1890s? A homebrew? Sounds cool.
I'd be more impressed if the climbers didn't have ladders and ropes pre-placed for them over certain difficult sections.
I remember that Larry Elmore's art was part of the attraction for me when I came upon these books in high school. Elmore art and the Dragonlance stories are inseparable in my mind.

WRITING.TITLE: I think "Mordenkainen" and "Fistandantilus" are both fantastic names for magic-users. What great names have you invented for wizards in your campaign?

WRITING.TEXT: I need an ELI5 on this subject! : )
So how does one know truth from fiction in articles like these, that seem legit?

WRITING.TEXT: My utility belts, too, are overburdened.
You play FATAL?
Wigs? Excellent.
There's a special place in the Nine Hells for min-maxing munchkins.
I mean, just look at my username.
So very true.

WRITING.TITLE: Am I the only one who enjoys a lengthy character creation process? So many RPGs these days tout their "5 minute character roll-up time." Man, I love spending hours on that stuff.

WRITING.TEXT: Sweet. Tell us more!
Now that's cool.
This.
You must be talking about younger players. The grognards seem to have a different play style. Still, I think a good GM can make a fun session out of any game system.
Agreed. This is 90% a DM issue.
Keep us updated.
Thanks for your detailed reply!
What kind of fuel are you using in the smoker?

As someone who is still learning, I'm curious to know when in the year you did your inspection and first noted high levels of infestation. If the bottom board has been collecting dead mites for a month, I assume you started treatment in early April?
Ah, got it. Fortunately, I've no personal experience with chalkbrood or wax moths, so these are things I'd need to study before taking the exam. Thanks for the tip!

The whole "doctoral thesis" aspect is part of what intrigues me. My full-time job is in academia, so I'm intrigued by the idea of blending that way of thinking with my hobby. But it's the public-service projects that concern me. Like most of us, I don't have much free time to dedicate to planting community gardens and lecturing at local clubs. I do see the value in those things, but I'm somewhat intimidated by them. Of course, that's years down the road for me, so I'm getting ahead of myself. At any rate, thanks for your thoughtful response.
Were you a commercial beekeeper before entering the program?

The practical exam for the first level sounded deceptively easy to me. I will take it eventually, though I wonder if I could pass it today, with what I've already learned. Was it really just as simple as identifying equipment and mites? Like, this is a brood chamber, this is a medium super, this is a Varroa, et cetera?
